text: I can think of a few reasons but I am curious as to why you think that <@UGV299K6H> ? And what sport would you suggest a newbie goes for now (if any) ?

elements.text: I can think of a few reasons but I am curious as to why you think that
? And what sport would you suggest a newbie goes for now (if any) ?

text: I'm curious too. I've been looking at Football and feel totally lost.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I'm curious too. I've been looking at Football and feel totally lost.

text:
Horse racing is declining quite quickly but has many sophisticated players who will battle it out 'till the last penny drains out because they have no reason not to.

If I were new I'd go to something with more robust volume and the prospect of growth. Cricket is the obvious thing right now.

Otherwise I'd head for anything with a lot of volume and frequent events. I might go for in-play football, there's plenty of money there and good volatility too. Personally I'd swerve tennis because it wouldn't play to my skills but it might suit someone else's.

text: I'd be all over football if the markets were left unmanaged. But I'd struggle with it due to VAR and all the complexities associated with goal cancellations etc. Plus the score feed that the website uses sometimes is woefully inaccurate. No doubt plenty here manage it though.

elements.text: I'd be all over football if the markets were left unmanaged. But I'd struggle with it due to VAR and all the complexities associated with goal cancellations etc. Plus the score feed that the website uses sometimes is woefully inaccurate. No doubt plenty here manage it though.

text: Does VAR mean that we probably can't trust Flumine backrest results for inplay football?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Does VAR mean that we probably can't trust Flumine backrest results for inplay football?

text: I don't see why VAR complications are any worse than the myriad things that can go awry in a horse racing market. Late non runners, bad TPD data, results being overturned after the race and so on. It's just another thing that you either build in or live with.

elements.text: I don't see why VAR complications are any worse than the myriad things that can go awry in a horse racing market. Late non runners, bad TPD data, results being overturned after the race and so on. It's just another thing that you either build in or live with.

text: Isn't it quite frequent that VAR cancels goals, which means that matched bets will be cancelled? But how to know which bets would have been cancelled? This sort of thing doesn't happen too often with horses.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text: I don't understand why that is a problem/blocker either

text: I suppose you could also just stick to non-VAR using leagues/countries anyway. I've seen over/under markets closed and reopened due to VAR in the past. Trying to gauge time added on and everything else. I'd definitely rather go for cricket with completely unmanaged markets and no nonsense to worry about.

text: VAR doesn't make much of a difference IMO. Your bets have +EV or they don't, VAR doesn't change reality. What has been an issue from time to time is untimely suspensions, and therefore matching after a goal has gone in (but market not closed). Can be resolved with a swift message to BF but still annoying it doesn't happen automatically. Nevertheless, quality of suspensions/market closures have improved over last half year or so.

text: For those of you doing large scale backtesting. Are you running it cloud or locally? and if cloud, are you just using for example S3, and fetching the data when you need it? Are you using block storage and moving the chunk of data you need to it to run your sims faster? Are you using snapshots of. block storage to save on data transfer, unzip and IOPS charges? Am I overthinking this?

text: Cloud. On GCP, so using GoogleCloudStorage (GCS), which has negligible fees on reading within the same zone

text:
Yeah <@U01DCR5PXDY> I’m considering the costs of keeping the unzipped data vs zipped and paying for compute to unzip. S3 -> Compute in the same region has no transfer cost, and s3 storage is half of the cost of block storage, but compute is generally more expensive than storage.

<@UPMUFSGCR> how much data zipped/unzipped is there for a year of GB? And if your setup is working locally stick with it. I’m just looking at cloud because I have a toaster for a dev machine and don’t want to spend the money upfront on the hardware to do it locally rn. Plus I work in cloud web dev for a day job so it’s familiar.

text: @James I have done cost experiments for zipped vs unzipped. I found unzipped to be cheaper in my use case. You should have cpu profiling working and be able to do such experiments yourself if you want to make optimizations of this kind. That being said, the financial choice is clear to just buy a better dev machine if that can fix your problem, unless your really not valuing your time to go the cloud route. It really is a time sink, trust me.

elements.text: @James I have done cost experiments for zipped vs unzipped. I found unzipped to be cheaper in my use case. text: If I were buying a machine for backtests, I'd build a desktop with the most powerful retail CPU on the market. And then in my case, model training is also memory heavy so I'd want minimum 128GB on that. Everything else wouldn't matter as much

text: Been a couple years since I looked at this stuff. I'd just buy whatever has the most cores. I don't use flumine backtesting, but I'd assume it can parallelize well

text: I do everything locally. 20tb of spinning storage for zipped historic data, 4tb of SSD for storing the working data set (last couple of years). I have the same data stored multiple times in different shapes optimised for different purposes. On CPU training is done on a ryzen thread ripper, 128gb ram (this is insufficient), on GPU is done on Nvidia 3090 with 24gb. These machines are just built into tower cases, and are on 247, don't underestimate the electricity bill.
